author: MilanGajic

description.text:
Another fan for prusa i4. No screws, self supports.
You can remove and easily put back.

WARNING!!! Since I designed this and have been running printers for several years with a couple recent near miss fire incidents, I've done a lot of thinking about fire safety. IT IS A REALLY BAD IDEA TO STORE FILAMENT ABOVE YOUR PRINTER. It's kind of like storing a bottle of gasoline above your kitchen stove. If your hotend happens to catch fire, it will almost certainly spread to the reel of fuel directly above it and then the rest of your house/office. Instead, put a fire detector or auto extinguisher directly above the printer and put the spool a distance away so if there is an incident you have some time to put it out while the fire is still small.
I built this stand to hold filament reels on top of my Mini Kossel.  The spool uses standard 608 skate bearings to create an effortless unwinding by the extruder.

title: Filament Spool Scale and Usage Meter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update: Universal spool holder for filament rolls up to 80mm wide. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2486863

The filament scale and usage meter is based on Arduino UNO and load cell with HX711. The scale and spool roller combination is able to provide continuous measurement of the weight of the filament spool, thus calculate the estimated length and the filament based on the density of the filament. It can also mark the start weight then track the actual change of spool weight before and during the print and display the difference. It can also measure the actual weight of the printed object as a regular table scale.

description.text:
Scale this model up to 104% so that it will fit. Also if your stepper motors don't have the notch between the end plates and the middle section, this design will not work for you. some steppers are smooth on the corners.

This is a NEMA 17 Stepper motor cooling system that works really well. My steppers used to get too hot to touch, but now it operates at close to room temperature. you will need 4 m3 X30mm screws and 4 m3 nuts. you can either use a 50 mm fan (which I haven't tried) or you can purchase this 40mm fan installed into an extruded aluminum heat sink.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005CFQ69W/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

you may also want to purchase some thermal adhesive so that the heat going to the sink is conducted heat versus convection heat.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0009B0K2I/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Please note that the thermal adhesive will not keep the heat sink attached by its self, since it is mounted vertically gravity will eventually take its toll.

Please post your makes! out of all my designs i still only have ONE make... :(

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

I used a .5 mm nozzle on the print in the picture with a .2 layer height. I also used 3 or 4 perimeters so that the bracket comes out solid. if the holes thread the screws, great. but otherwise drill them through and use the nuts. have fun

comments.text: Have you tried turning the current down, if its getting too hot to touch, you are overpowering your stepper motors, reducing life expectancy and it could even be creating issues within your prints, its not hard to turn down the current, can be done manually (via a multi turn pot) or via software, depending on what printer you have/software you use.
comments.author: woggin

comments.text: I slightly exadurated the temp they would get to,  long prints id say they are around 70-90c. The motors are rated up to 140-150c before they damage themselves.  I just took heat transfer last semester as an engineering student,  and how I see it is that the surface area to thermal mass ratio doesn't allow heat to escape nearly quick enough.  Adding a heat sink increases the convection coefficient by increasing the surface area,  while not adding as much thermal mass.  I'm pretty proud of how cool my x axis runs now.  Also  keeping the current up slightly will keep the motors from coming off a step.  Id rather keep the Torque and cool my motors,  then risk failing prints.   This is a valid upgrade.
comments.author: woggin

comments.text: The link you provided for the 40mm fan and heat sink points to the product for adhesive pads.  Please post the link to the Amazon product for the combined fan and heat sink.

title: Senese's CT-Scanned Skull
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is my skull.

It's a fairly complex model extracted from a CT scan using the Osirix Lite software. There is still a lot of noisy artifacts in the model from external elements picked up by the CT scanning process (air mask, tubes). I'll eventually do a cleanup of the model to eliminate those.

Nasal area of skull is splayed outwards in this model, due to impact from a car accident.

Works well with SLS printing; I've successfully printed it on FDM using Cura and an Ultimaker 2+.

title: Canon 8mm Bayonet Mount to D-Mount Converter (prototype)

description.text:
This mount allows you to retrofit Canon bayonet mount 8mm lenses (produced in 1957) to common D-mount adapters that will fit popular digital SLR cameras. The lenses work best with Pentax Q digital cameras. Please feel free to update this print with d-mount threads. You will have to make the shaft longer to gently use a tap/die set to create some threads. Otherwise you can use tape to secure the mount to the lens and adapter plate. Be careful since PLA can shear when in use if the lens gets knocked 90-degrees to the shooting axis. In case you were interested in the lenses, I have a write up of them and the original cameras, here: http://super8man.filmshooting.com/super8_44.html
Good luck! Let me know on any mods.

This enclosure may fit Prusa i3 ET-MB 2 / MPX .3 / MKS Base 1.3 / 1.4﻿ boards. Im not exactly sure they all use the same hole spacing. But incorporating this board is pretty involved.

the factory green power header has to be de-soldered and the wires are soldered directly to the board. I also purchased a kit of locking JST connectors (from 2 -9 wide) https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01JCEPATK/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
this uses a 4, 7 and 8 wide connector that I left 3 wires open for future upgrades.

The bed wire strain relief (2 pieces) should be slid into place within the bottom section, then drilled out to the correct diameter for your bed wires.

The Fan cover should be printed with no top and bottom layers and the infill is the grill, so get creative!!

here is the 50mm fan that I used https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B018JWEV8W/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Please post your makes, and comment if you have any questions. Mine is up and running now!

comments.text: I'll post some next time I open it up.  Just be aware, like it says in the description, you have to desolder the factory header (green screw term block) and solder your own leads to the appropriate connector. This is far from a plug and play design.  Once you've modified everything, it's easier to connect and disconnect the board via locking jst connectors.  Although initially, it's going to require your own maker sauce to get it made.  "the mission is risky, should you choose to accept" good luck

author: nyrfan

description.text:
I wanted a simple and quick to print but still useful test to fine-tune a multitude of parameters, so i made this. This is not a test to test the limits for your printer, but rather finding a "good enough".

These are some of the things i can test with it:

  • Dimensions: The basic cube is 20mm, the holes are 10mm and the well on top is 16x16mm on the inside with 2mm thick walls.
  • Layer adhesion: Use pliers to break the upper wall off or put the pliers in the round hole trying to pry the block apart.
  • Stringing: If stringing is a problem you will see it in the holes and/or the well.
  • Ringing: Could be seen around the holes, corners, or dimples around the well.
  • Surface smoothness: Both walls and top layers are visible.
  • Loose belts: Look for weird artifacts around the rounded corners.
  • Overhangs: The overhang on the outside is easy, the round hole might be a bit harder but not insane.
  • Bridging: Mainly tested by the square hole.

Let me know what more you can test with this little print.

Designed in OnShape: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/b278982bdf8aa44b7bf4ae93/w/856541142d3cd3b8c6950523/e/c988254dcece2c47b9786b2c

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 E3D V6 Conversion WIP

description.text:
Although still currently a WIP that's only because i'm trying to think of a better way to mount my inductive sensor, just ask if you want the plans atm. Ignore my terrible quality photos and my terrible wire management. The actual printed piece itself is extremely rigid and is made out of ABS and should thus be able to resist the heat given off by the heated bed and extruder without softening or warping.

This is a remix of Evaken's remix of PiggyJJ's E3d V6 conversion for the Duplicator I3. In order to use this you will need to download and print AzzA's Z extensions for the I3 V2 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1444979) as these will help compensate for the loss in z height caused by the V6 being larger than the MK 10 hotend. I have made my own custom versions that increase the z height by another 30 mm which i might upload if requested. Essentially by moving the extruder higher up on the gantry i am able to recover lost z height by simply having more space underneath the top bar. In all my testing this does not seem to impact printing performance. Would highly reccomend the mod although it does look rather strange.
I have recently found a fantastic Z-Probe mount that is compatible with this mod and is much better than my own. Thanks to HoolyHoo for the awesome design! https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1960419

author: Tommyph1208

description.text:
We're working on a show card image for our upcoming exhibition at Firecat Gallery in Chicago. The title of the show is "Dialogues on the New Plastic" which is a quote (more or less) from the famous Dutch abstract painter Piet Mondrian.   
In the original text "Dialogue on the New Plastic" Mondrian imagines a conversation between a musician and himself. In the scene Mondrian explains his shift from representational paintings to more abstracted images - the new plastic.   
We wanted to re-create one of Mondrian's images (as a 3D print) for the show card - but his signature grids / compositions just did not seem likely to translate too well. instead we decided to work towards an image derived from one of his tree paintings early in his career where he is beginning to reduce these natural forms down to simple curve and colors and to flatten the composition in general.  
We went for a short walk around our neighborhood with the Sense and my laptop and scanned as best we could as many trees as we could. We knew that the Sense would not capture the forms in full - but rationalized that this would create arbitrary breaks in the forms not unlike Mondrian's paintings. Furthermore we thought that these scans joined together would in effect produce a cubist tree - that is a subject seen from many different angles as a single form or composition.  
These are the raw scans - if it goes well - later i'll post the tree.

author: chiheb32

description.text:
It is to be used to instantly cool 3d printed chocolate with an -15 degree Celsius air stream. This is a Ranque-Hilsch effect vortex tube cooler inspired by this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8114 The chocolate cooler can be helpfull for those of you who are using the Chocolate Extruder thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18017 Because printed hot chocolate layers are to be hardened before they will support the next hot chocolate layer there is a necessity to quickly cool the chocolate filament after it was printed. The vortex tubes are used in industry for spot cooling applications so the idea is to spot cool the chocolate as well. The vortex tube exhaust at one end hot air and at the cold end cool air at as low as -25 degree Celsius from a compressed air source at 5 bar. Some links to vortex cooling chocolate:
http://www.exeter.ac.uk/news/research/title_145191_en.html
http://blog.exair.com/2011/11/01/refrigerated-air-from-compressed-air/

Before starting to build the vortex cooler please keep in mind you will need an air compressor capable of delivering 4 to 5 bar.
Print the parts. The Vortex_generator.stl part will need a little bit of support to be printed but then is easy to remove support material. Sandpaper carefully especially the vortex generator. This is the place where the compressed air enters tangentialy trough the 4 chanells and vortex is created.
The hot end part is comprised from two parts which needs to be glued together. I used Bison two parts epoxy glue which sets in 5 minutes and is very strong. Here you need to accomodate and M3 nut BEFORE glueing. Then drill a small hole in to the cone you will find in part Hot_End_1.stl and glue it to an M3 bolt already screwed in the coresponding nut. Then you can glue the parts together. Screwing or un-screwing will set the final temperature at the both ends. As a general rule, if less air will escape at the hot end, cooler the air will be at the cool end oriffice.
The cone at the hot end can be manufactured from any other material. The cone supplied in the stl file is pretty small and may not keep good shape during printing.
Also you will need some rubber gasket when joining the vortex generator and the vortex generator lid. Use 5xM3 nuts and bolts to secure the parts.
For the vortex tube I am using brass tube. Aluminium is ok too. The vortex tube dimensions: 8mmOD X 6mmID X 180mm. However the tube lenght shoud be anything between 20 < Lenght/Inner diameter < 55. Please experiment as this ratios are very important for cooling efficiency. Also the cold end oriffice which is found in the vortex generator should be something around 3mm. Again please experiment.
You can accomodate some kind of metalic tube at the cold end to attach a hose duct. The hose duct should came close to the chocolate printing nozzle so the cool air can spread across the printed layer.

title: Snap-together Oddish Planter Remix Redux
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This remixed planter has snap-on legs that can be printed separately, plus a pluggable drain hole for bamboo and carnivorous plants that require submerged roots.

Since sometimes components don't fit together precisely, I've also provided a body without holes.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I printed off the planter seen in the photos with white HatchBox PLA. This filament is not FDA rated but it is eco-friendly, so your plants will probably be okay.

Use 100% fan cooling speed, 205 °C extrusion and a 60 °C bed temperature. Three bottom layers helped fill all the gaps, and five outer shells should keep the inside from getting too messy (and developing additional holes for water to leak through).

Print the body and plug upside-down. The bolts are slightly longer than the body and you'll need to add supports to the bottom if you don't print it upside-down.

author: ydkim

description.text:
Wish you had a snakey, spiral-ly magic wand? Here's your chance!
Aside from that, this is an experiment in using OpenSCAD's linear_extrude function, twisting and extruding a circle to form a cool magic rod. I then use the same technique to make screws and screw holes, allowing me to make a long magic wand. This technique of making screws and nuts is pretty simple to code and looks like it'll work well. Note that the screws and holes are pointed, so that the holes can print with 45 degree slopes inside (i.e. so no bridging).
The way the sphere fits onto the head of the wand also looks pretty nifty, if I say so myself.
I haven't printed it yet. (Waiting for Replicator....). When I print one, I'll update here.

You can print the STL as-is, scaled to fit your printer, screw the parts together, and have a five segment magic wand. If you have 'glow in the dark' filament, that would probably be ideal. Play around with the parameters to generate wands of different sizes. In particular: h = height of a rod segment
cr = radius of the circle that forms the rod
w = distance of 'wiggle' in the rod, 2 is subtle, 10 is wacky (and might generate angles over 45 degrees)
nw = number of 'wiggles' in each rod segment
gap = the distance between each screw and the hole in the next rod segment
spacing = the spacing between rod segments arranged in a row and 'plated'. If you make the rod very wide, you will need to increase the spacing as well.
c = 'crossiness'. 0 = spiral, 1 = spiral and counter-spiral, 2 = four spirals, forms cross pattern. Uncomment 'stacked()' and comment 'plated()' to view the rod as it would assemble. Switch back to print. If you want more rod segments, add more mid() statements into 'plated' until you have as many as you like. Don't forget to translate them so that they don't overlap with other rod segments.

comments.text: I tired making this project a few times and it would get to the 75% completion and then pegs would come off and / or mess the print.
comments.author: Guzzie

comments.text: I printed it, and while the top and bottom parts are fine, the 'screw' for the middle sections is rotated incorrectly so the outer spiral isn't properly aligned. I'll fix it and update here shortly.
comments.author: laird

comments.text: Finally printed it, and I'm very pleased. In particular, the spiral screws and screw holes work perfectly, so the segments join together smoothly, and with exactly the right rotation so the surface spiral is continuous across the joins. And it prints with no support, making it a very clean print. I just uploaded a photo of a "fat" magic wand, and I'm printing a thinner one as well. Magical fun! =-X
comments.author: laird

comments.text: I printed a long wand, and while the top and bottom pieces fit together perfectly, the threads on the middle connectors need to be rotated - when they're screwed together the outer spiral isn't continuous.
comments.author: laird

comments.text: Wow ... make sure you dip that in acetone to make it smooth, otherwise it could be very uncomfortable in your ... hand.
comments.author: Whystler

comments.text: The next version will light up! More magic!
comments.author: Whystler

comments.text: Funny how a 3 KB OpenSCAD script can generate an 18 MB STL file. Extruding a circle into a spiral mesh generates a lot of data points, even if the resolution isn't particularly high.
comments.author: laird

line1 = TREVOR
Turtle STL or "turstl" for the nerds with nurbs.

Building a Nixie Clock is a time honored tradition among makers, and this is yet another DIY Nixie Clock project. This one is unique in a few respects: 1) it uses an ESP8266 development board as the microcontroller, allowing it to automatically sync its time to NIST over WiFi, and 2) it features a 3D printed frame and hand-solderable PCB.

When the clock is turned on for the first time, it will create a WiFi access point that you will need to connect to using a computer or smartphone. The user can use this access point to specify the WiFi network SSID and password. This information is stored in EEPROM, so will not be needed the next time the clock is turned on. It uses the Arduino Wifi Manager to create the access point. See the GitHub link for more information.

The OLED screen and rotary encoder are used to specify the time offset from UTC time. Pressing the encoder button accesses the menu-driven settings. This offset is stored in EEPROM. The settings menu is also used to enable auto-daylight savings time adjustment. It assumes the current US daylight savings time rules. If the auto adjustment isn't enabled, the UTC time offset will need to be updated anytime DST begins or ends.

Please PM me if you would like a set of printed circuit boards. I have enough extras to make a few more ESP Nixie clocks. You will need to purchase the ICs and other components, but those can easily be found on eBay, Amazon, and all the other usual places. I'm not trying to make money off of this project, so can offer the main board and four Nixie tube boards for a small amount (let's say $10). I even have a few extra NodeMCU ESP8266 boards, and can throw one in for $5 more.

Parts
  • NodeMCU V1.0 (Amica board). Clone boards often are unofficially labeled as V2
  • 4 IN-14 Nixie Tubes
  • 1 0.96" I2C 128x64 OLED display
  • 1 Rotary Encoder
  • 1 12VDC 1A Wall Adapter Power Supply
  • 1 NCH6100HV High Voltage DC Power Supply (or equivalent)
  • 1 Nixie Board PCB. I've included the Eagle schematic, board layout, and gerber files in this repository.
  • 2 15-pin female headers
  • Lots of male breakaway headers (I haven't counted, buy a pack)
  • 6 16-pin DIP IC Sockets
  • 4 Nixie Tube PCBs. Files included in this repository. This can also easily be created using a strip board.
  • 2 74HC595N shift registers
  • 4 74141N BCD to Decimal Decoders (or K155ID1 Russian equivalents)
  • 1 L7805 5V regulator
  • 1 0.33 uF capacitor
  • 1 0.1 uF capacitor
  • 1 3 Pin 5.08mm Pitch PCB Mount Screw Terminal
  • 1 2 Pin 5.08mm Pitch PCB Mount Screw Terminal
  • 4 15K Ohm resistors
  • (optional) 1 20K Ohm resistor
  • Various M2 and M3 bolts
  • 8 female-female short jumper wires.

Most of these parts can be found on eBay or your favorite online Chinese retailer. Although no longer manufactured, nixie tubes are still readily available, with the IN-14 selling for about $5-$10 per tube. I recommend the NCH6100HV power supply, though there are many others out there capabile of driving Nixie tubes. The output voltage should be set to 170 V, which can be adjusted using an onboard potentiometer. If selecting a different power supply, make sure it is capable of delivering at least 15 mA of continuous current at 170 V.

Instructions

The Nixie Board PCB and tube PCBs must be manufactured by a PCB supplier. The least expensive way to do this is to upload the gerber files (included as a .zip file) to one of several Chinese manufacturers such as ShenZhen2U, EasyEDA, or Seeed Studio. pcbshopper.com allows a comparison between vendors. Typical prices are $1-$3/board, with a minimum of 5 boards. Recommended default settings are Layers: 2; PCB Thickness: 1.6mm; Surface Finish: HASL; Copper Weight: 1. The main board is 100 x 80 mm, and the smaller tube boards are 20.7mm x 28.3mm. (Alternatively, contact me since I may still have a few extras I could send out for $10.)

Solder headers, IC sockets, terminal blocks, resistors, voltage regulator, and capacitors to the board. The 0.33 uF capacitor goes closest to the 2-pin terminal block. The 20K Ohm resistor is marked as optional. This will illuminate the decimal point between the hours and minutes. Personally, I think it looks better without it and I did not use it, but it is there if others wish to use it. Mount ICs, and NodeMCU to the headers and sockets.

3D print the parts. The top cover is printed on its side, and will need supports to prevent the tube holes from sagging. Four tube sockets are required.

Mount Nixie tubes through 3D printed tube sockets, and then through the tube PCBs. You may (optionally) use a stripboard instead of the tube PCB. Be careful to make sure the anode wire (the rear wire on the tube with an arrow pointing to it) goes through the PCB hole that connects to the center pin of the 7-pin header. I should have marked it on the PCB. Also, the side of the PCB with the traces is the top side. It will not plug into the board if the tube is soldered to the wrong side.

Mount the board to the 3D printed base with M3 bolts, and the OLED and HV power supply with M2 bolts. Mount the rotary encoder to the back of the case. Wire the 2-pin terminal block to the 12V wall power supply, and the 3-pin terminal block to the HV power supply using loose wire. The GND can go to either side of the HV power supply, but make sure the terminal labelled 12V goes to Vin, and terminal labelled 170V goes to HV. Connect the OLED to the four OLED pins on the board using jumper cables. The rotary encoder should have three pins on one side and two on the other. Connect the three pins to the 3 ENC headers on the board, and the two pins to the 2 BTN pins on the board. If the jumper cables on the encoder are loose, you may wish to solder them on directly. I did.

Upload the firmware to the NodeMCU board using the Arduino IDE and a micro USB cable. There are plenty of tutorials on how to configure the Arduino IDE (such as here) so I won't cover it in this Readme. Note that a number of libraries are required, most of which can be installed through the Arduino Library Manager. Specifically, you will need NTPClient, Adafruit GFX, Adafruit SSD1306, EEPROM, ESP8266WiFi, Time, Wifi, WifiManager, and Wire. In addition, you will need the Timezone library that is not available in the Library Manager, but must be manually installed by adding it to the Arduino libraries folder. Timezone can be found here. Finally, you will need a copy of Albert van Dalen's terrific Switch library, found here.

Glue the case side panels to the top cover. I use plastic epoxy. Close the case and attach on the side corners using (optional) 1/2" #4 or #6 sheet metal screws.

Plug it in and enjoy!

(Note: Detailed build instructions can also be found on GitHub)

Notes:

I suggest to test if your printer can print the edge inside of the reservoir before printing this massive flowerpot, I've made a test piece for that.

Take notice that
  • Everything has < or = 45° angle's
  • Small overhang in reservoir

Pot has been successfully printed.
Reservoir had some issues failed to print 45° angle'd C ring inside of it, this should be fixed in the 2.6 model (i printed it without any problems).
The 2.6 model also has a better fillet on the bottum of it, the >45° overhang bit is removed from it.

If the reservoir leaks, you could use glue (second glue, wood glue, hotglue..) to close the holes or just give the whole inside a layer. Use a brush to get an even layer.

1.2 (3/12/16)

  • Added a triangle shaped ring inside of the reservoir too keep the flower pot straight & raised
  • Added chamfer so the pot goes in easier and a fillet for the looks.

2.3 (4/12/16)

  • Expanded flowerpot so it filled up the whole reservoir. -> misjudged length.
  • Thickened flowerpot_Pot wall of small cilinder. -> wanted 2mm but it was 1mm.
  • New fillet on all parts. -> better looks.
  • Better circular edge inside of the reservoir. -> prev one couldn't be printed.

comments.text: I also just wanted to mention that you'll have better luck printing overhangs if you speed up your printer (just for the overhang + too fast wont be able to stick and too slow will droop down) also set your nozzle temp lower with a higher fan rate (it will be solid before it droops down and will cool faster). Printing slower will give it more time to droop (the fillament will be in the nozzle longer, heat up more + the nozzle will be next to the fillament also heating it up.

Also, we've set up a Patreon page for anyone who'd like to support us in keeping our toys open source.

Thank you for looking, happy gaming!

title: Mini Trash Can with moving wheels

description.text:
I like the 3D-Fuel Mini trash can, but it lacks something. Moving wheels! I therefore remixed it so now it is exactly like the real thing.
I also slightly increased the inside volume for that little bit of extra trash capacity.

The wheels come in two variants, if you have a hard time making the regular wheels spin, try the ‘widerHole’ ones. Of course, reaming the hole will help as well (I have found the inside measuring prongs of a caliper to work well for this, and it allows to immediately see how much wider you have made the hole!)

Another change w.r.t. the original model, is that the lid is hollow (again, more like the real thing). This makes it slightly more difficult to print, but the hollow lid is lighter, hence reduces the risk that the bin will topple over with the lid open. It also provides a wee bit of extra room to pile up junk! The solid lid from the original model will of course still fit and it may be easier to print, but it can be difficult to remove from your platform due to the enormous contact surface.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm and 0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed in silver and black ABS, the main body in 0.2 mm, the rest 0.1.
My print shows some cracks because I was testing some new settings with too aggressive cooling.

The lid with built-in supports should be an easy print and will probably use less material than auto-generated supports. The supports can be removed with pliers, don't pull on them but wiggle them sideways to break them loose. There is also a plain model in case you prefer to use your own slicer's supports.
If you print the lid in a warp-prone filament, it is advisable to use a brim or raft to improve contact surface with the bed, otherwise the corners may lift and it won't be a perfect fit.

If for some reason the lid is too difficult to print, you can always fall back to the original solid lid.

If you want to print the bin and lid in different types of filaments with different shrinkage factors (e.g. ABS and PLA), you may have to scale up the part printed in the filament that shrinks the most by a fraction of a percent, otherwise it could be hard or impossible to mount the lid, or it may be too sloppy.
If you have difficulty mounting the lid, use a knife to remove any material that seems to be in the way. This can be the case especially if your first layer is squashed too much.

2017/01/19: v2

Increased the wall thickness at the top where it was rather thin. Also created a version of the insert without a bottom, useful if you want to use the trashcan as a holder for pens or other long tools.

2017/05/18: v3, lid v2

Made the lid hollow, like the real thing. Also nudged the wheels outwards for slightly better stability.

title: BeagleBone Black slim case - OSHW remix

description.text:
Features

This is a remix of Sluttlebot's amazing, parametric Beaglebone Black Slim Case. My additions are:

  • Larger gap between board and case
    Increased the clearance between board and case from 0.25mm to 0.5mm.
  • Wall mounting tabs
    Set an option to select between 2, 4, or no wall mounting tabs. Tabs have holes for #8 screws by default -- the diameter can be modified by changing the value of Screw_Hole_D in the BBB_OSHW_Case_Library.scad file.
  • Ventilation hole in lid
    Hole is in the shape of the Open Source Hardware logo, and can be rotated any of four directions.
  • Fixed jumps while printing
    Tweaked curve generation to use power-of-two numbers so that edges line up perfectly.

Editing

You will need the base SCAD file, the library file, and the OSHW logo DXF in the same directory to work. The base scad file has several options at the top to modify what model is generated. The settings and their effects are listed in the comments.

Licence info

This remix is licenced under the GPL. The Open Source Hardware logo is licenced under CC-BY-SA, which I understand to be compatible with the GPL.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

No

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Pick appropriate speeds for your printer and flow rate for your nozzle (the Di3's Mk10 nozzle can do about 3.5mm³/sec). Let Slic3r automatically determine the extrusion width (set everything to 0 and leave the first layer at 200%).

Alternatively, do the math yourself to work out what extrusion width is appropriate for the 1.5mm walls of the case.

title: RAMPS 1.4 and Arduino Mega 2560 Mount for 25mm 8020 Extruded Aluminum
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update: See this thing for a variation of this Arduino and Ramps mount that hangs an LCD display vertically from the extruded aluminum, and allows the Arduino and RAMPS to be mounted directly to the backplate.

Simple RAMPS 1.4 mount for 25mm 8020 aluminum extrusion. Mounts to Arduino Mega 2560 and RAMPS, which I bought together on Amazon in this 3D printer electronics kit. Keeps all electronic connections exposed for easy access and good cooling of stepper drivers. Also, mount is angled to conveniently hide the RAMPS board behind a mounted full graphics LCD display (see picture of LCD with RAMPS behind it). Here is the link to that LCD case and mount.

Required Hardware

  • 3 M3x25mm (minimum) screws
  • 3 each M3 nuts and washers
  • 2 each M6 washers, T-nuts, and bolts (length may vary depending on your set up, I used 12mm long bolts, the 3D printed mount is 4mm thick at bolt holes)

Note: All 4 holes for the Arduino are printed in the mount, however only 3 are accessible with the RAMPS board installed.

A ventilated shield for measuring outdoor air temperature and humidity (e.g., on a weather station).

Three parts that must be bolted together using four 2 inch  6-32 machine screws with four nuts and washers - four 20 mm spacers are needed between the fan and cap (can be made from vinyl tubing slipped over the screws).  Forced ventilation can achieved using any 40mm x 40mm x 10mm DC axial fan (a larger 20 mm thick fan can also be used).  Initial testing was done with ADDA AD0405HB-G70 (5V, 6.7 CFM). The barrel is designed to house a Humidity and Temperature Sensor - SHT15 Breakout - from Sparkfun Electronics, but other sensors could be employed. The entire shield should be mounted to a horizontal pipe using a U-bolt (1 3/8 inch internal spacing)

I bought a PrintinZ print bed for my XYZ DaVinci Pro.
http://www.printinz.com/
My binder clips were either too big or too small so I made my own.
2 clamps at 20mm wide go in the front.
1 clamp 10mm wide goes in the back.
Print in ABS with 50% infill.
There is a brim on the bottom. trim off post print.

R1 - It seems that after a couple of months of printing, my hex clamps get weak and the printinz plate starts to slide around a little. I made these screw type clamps to get more pressure. I used an 8-32 screw 3/4" long and a 8-32 nut. I wouldn't put a screwdriver on them, just tighten them by hand.
Two will go in the front, but they are too big for the back. Not even upside down, one of the linear shafts will hit the screw when zeroing the axes. Maybe a 1/2" screw?
I used my hex clamp(s) in the back for now.

R2 - I made a smaller screw clamp. I started with my hex clamp and modified it to accept an 8-32 nut and screw. This one even fits on the back side if you flip it upside down and use a shorter screw.

Edit: Sept 9 2017 Updated stl to solid thicker piece. This should last longer before breaking.

Does your lee turret press not auto index properly anymore? Your square ratchet is probably worn out. It's simply a piece of plastic so I modeled and printed a replacement in about 10 minutes. You'll want to use a plastic that bonds the layers very nicely. I used PETG. ABS may also work but I'm not sure. Let me know if it does.

You want a loose fit on the rod with this piece. If it is not, try scaling it down or up a bit.

Printer:

Kossel XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/QmKO8c7Lm2E" ></iframe>
It works

comments.text: Even though these are cheap its great to make on your own.  PETG is too brittle most of the time.  ABS is OK but this will be great with matterhackers black nylon.  Glass bed, glue + brim makes this nylon the first true engineering grade material i can print with.

description.text:
A pack of four cosmetic nozzles for model rockets.  
Centuri Inlet and Centuri Nozzle are recreations of the nozzles that were used on the Quasar, SST Transport, and USS America kits. These fit a ST-5 which is close enough in model rocket science to a BT-5.   
Estes nozzle is a recreation of the nozzle believed to have originated with their original X-Wing kit.  Fits a BT-5.  
Nozzle is a generic pseudo-scale nozzle that I created just to dress up model rockets. Since it is a bit thick walled and the "circles" have only 24 sides, I suggest only scaling it smaller.

It has a side length of 90mm and the slot for the glass has a diameter of about 50mm so you might want to scale it if you want to use special shot glasses.

description.text:
I was asked to make a VESA bracket clamp for a VIVO 3 computer monitor stand. The clamp is designed to fit the VIVO tube or any 35mm diameter tube and provide 4 VESA mounting holes. The original use was to hold small computers, but if you wanted to hold a large monitor or heavy object, I would print out 2 clamps.

They are designed for SAE (Imperial) bolts, but metric bolts will also work.
The two clamp bolts are 1/4-20 x 1-1/2 length plus 2 nuts.
For the VESA holes I used two #8-32 x 1 length plus 2 nuts.
You can also use 6mm x 40mm bolts and nuts for the clamp and 4mm x 25mm bolts and nuts for the VESA mount.

Printer:

XYZ da Vinci Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25 mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed these in ABS on glass with glue stick. No supports were needed. Also, by upping the infill to 25%, you could drill additional holes for whatever you were mounting--say a 4 port switch or whatnot.

Design in 123d Design

I have included the 123d Design file in case you want/need to change it to fit your project.

print_settings.Notes:: If printing on an FFF printer, use supports for the dish. Infill doesnt matter as long as there are no holes in your pieces.

description.text:
This thing creates a customizable Cassegrain Reflector dish. It was created using the equations from the paper by Peter Hannan, "Microwave antennas derived from the cassegrain telescope," in IRE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation, vol. 9, no. 2, pp. 140-153, March 1961.

Suggestions for use as a tool:
►Stick the waveguide in you ear, see what you can hear.
►Glue aluminum foil to the main and secondary reflectors, and use it as a flashlight by putting an LED in the waveguide.
►Glue aluminum foil to the main and secondary reflectors, stick a coil of wire in the waveguide, and use it as a radio receiver.
►Glue aluminum foil to the main and secondary reflectors, stick an IR photodiode in the waveguide, and use it in photo-communications projects. Bonus points if you mod one of your home entertainment systems to use this!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Normal/Medium

Infill:

Doesn't matter

Notes:

If you are using customizer, playing with values, use the "mockup" mode. If you want to print it straight (which you should only use if you are using a resin printer or Shapeways or another fused dust printer), then use "solid". "For printing" should be used on a FFF printer (most of you). If using an FFF printer, the pieces are arranged so that they can be printed best on a flat bed. Feel free to rearrange the pieces on your slicer. The STLs provided will work if scaled all by the same amount, but the physics will not work out if you have different scaling for x,y,z.

If printing on an FFF printer, use supports for the dish. Infill doesnt matter as long as there are no holes in your pieces.

Once all the pieces are printed, the waveguide gets glueed (I recommend a clear superglue, like cyanoacrylate) to the back of the main reflector. The struts get glued to the main reflector and the secondary reflector. The bulge on the scondary reflector is supposed to point towards the concave part of the main reflector. The spike looking thing is a ruler. You stick the thin end in the hole of the main reflector, and the secondary reflector sits on top of the ruler, so that you know how far apart they are supposed to be. The thin part of the ruler measuers the distance between the reflecting face of the main reflector, and where the focus/sensor/microphone/speaker/lightbulb is supposed to be. Check "mockup" mode if you are unsure how the pieces are supposed to be arranged. The ruler is not to be glued to any pieces. Remove the ruler (I guess by cutting it in half) once you have assembled the struts and secondary reflector.

Cassegrain reflectors are used in radio telescopes, and are based off of the optical Cassegrain Telescopes. While Cassegrain reflectors will work theoretically with any wave, the physics assumptions that they are designed with assume that the distance between the main and secondary reflectors is more than 3 wavelengths. This can present problems if you are using this for Radio or Sound waves. But, if you know enough physics to want to use a cassegrain reflector as a tool, you can figure out how to calculate the wavelength of the signal you are using (Hint: λ=v/f).

comments.text:
Just what I need - thanks!
I am trying to make an acoustic torch as a blind aid.
I want the system to be as flat as possible and I am first testing - focal length 35 - diameter 150 - waveguide 0 - small mirror 36 mm
It looks fine as a solid but for 3D printing the struts lie in a heap and nothing is on the base plate
It is printing now with 2 struts as a solid - I guess with lots of support to crack off.
It could be efficient as a solid if the struts were replaced by vertical thin sheets - indeed I may leave the support under them since they block the beam substantially anyway.
Is it possible make a version like that and also have the diameter of the hole variable so I can fit the ultrasonic drive exactly?
I will of course credit you if and when I find blind "customers"!
Thanks again.

title: Christmas Ornament
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Having passed the US Presidential election, like a large kidney store, I thought it would be nice to help others share the joys of the Christmas holiday.

This is my Christmas Gift to you.

  • the image was printed with the colors reversed.

Printer:

Flashforge Creater Dual

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

7

Notes:

The speed is 40/40. It takes about 90 minutes to print. It uses about 7 meters of filament

BahHumbug.gcode is a dual print. Put the Red on head 1. Put the Green on head 2.
I used Hatchbox abs at 230/100 degrees.

For you single headed people, use red.stl, and green.stl. The green print is intended to be mounted above the red print, so it is 5 mm above the print bed. If you don't want to print it that way, use your slicer to put it on the print bed before printing.

BahHumbug.scad was used to generate the two stl files. RepG was used to merge the stl files into the single gcode file.

A Merry Christmas to all, and to all a good night.
use a paper clip, through the hole at the top, to make a tree hanger

description.text:
This is my first upload to Thingiverse! Thanks for viewing. If there is enough interest, I will update this with an alternate, more "plain" band which you can customize yourself. But for now, I'm just uploading the band with the design I made.

This is a fully 3D-Printable 22mm standard watch band, which I designed to be printed in NinjaFlex or any other flexible TPU/TPE filament. For my example, I printed the watch's band in Ninjaflex grass green, and the holders in Hatchbox TPU black.

With just a little cleanup (There will likely be some stringing from TPU) you should be able to use existing watch band hardware to attach this band to a standard watch. The band is 22mm wide where it connects to the watch face, and tapers down to 20mm to properly fit into most buckles.

description.text: Binder Clip

We were getting frustrated with slow crimping. While not doing enough volume to warrant an automatic machine we augmented our hand crimps to make the job a little bit easier. (for more details and how to build your own http://oomlout.co.uk/blog/WCRH )

Once cut from 3 & 6 mm sheet stock the pieces should go together quite logically. Then grab a cheap pair of of the shelf hand crimps (we used these pair http://oom.lt/yXUoiR ) cut the bits out and bolt together. You'll be effortlessly crimping in no time.

description.text:
Took the original model and scaled it up 150%. Sits at 22" Dia.
is made to have a network of pipe-cleaners to act as a self-watering/self-draining pipe into a bowl located in the plant hanger via capillary action and gravity, it's theoretical but I am confident it will work. Also provided files for mounting light fixtures with a 1/2" npt thread fitting.

this will most likely take you a month to print and $100 of filament. It's a commitment!

Also provided my working solidworks files; do note that i had to rework the outer ring parts

Pursa Mendel

No

No

17% (go as low as you can!)

no supports would be needed. i used PLA

Assembly note

the holes are for screws. to thread for PLA(if you dont have taps), chamfer the hole wth a large bit (by hand) then heat up the screw till it is hot, but note hot enough to burn your lips, then slowly screw it in while applying pressure. NOTE: screwing in too fast will cause it to heat up and before the surrounding plastic. everything should side together, hammer if necassary.

description.text:
I saw this thing on amazon.
https://www.amazon.com/iGaging-100-D68-Caliper-Attachment-Calipers/dp/B00M78245C/ref=pd_sim_469_3?_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_i=B00M78245C&pd_rd_r=VE5MT28X073550GZJ0EV&pd_rd_w=b0IG9&pd_rd_wg=7hdcY&psc=1&refRID=VE5MT28X073550GZJ0EV

$18 seems a bit steep for my $17 4 inch caliper. So I made my own. I used a M4 screw for a set screw and a M4 ultrasonic insert. They are available from Global Industrial for $5.00 for 100 of them. For those unfamiliar with these inserts, you just heat them with a soldering iron and they sink right into a properly sized hole and now you have metal threads!

http://www.globalindustrial.com/product/itemKey/30435445

The Onshape design is available here:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/c5d1c16f1719cb7038a51541/w/0ecade61c7dcd5756392f292/e/f950a21c6f616f9119e69327

Right now, this is only for the 4" caliper but I plan to make a version for the 6" caliper.

description.text:
Remixed from the PLA Wrist Brace.

Please note I am not a veterinarian and this thing serves only to show concept of design. Please consult your local vet if your pet is injured.

Instructions:
-Print with PLA or other low temp filament to allow for post printing thermoforming
-Print flat with strap loops on the upper surface. I did not have to use support structure.
-You can form the shape by dipping the part in boiling water for a few seconds or using a hairdryer to heat the part.

  • Once heated the part becomes malleable for a few seconds. I formed the shape by hand and test fitted to the shape of the cats leg. I repeated the process as necessary, dipping in only the area I wanted to shape in the boiling water.

description.text:
My first attempt at a contribution. Designed to hold the power and thermistor wires securely to the hotend/extruder assembly. I was worried they may snag on something and fall out. The way I assembled my A8, I didn't have anywhere else suitable to zip tie them to and I wasn't happy with the sticky pad as it kept lifting when hot (although it probably would have been OK). Attaches to 2 existing, vacant, threaded holes on the back of the plate with short M3 screws. Could also be zip tied. Very much work in progress. Seems to do the trick.

Needs to be printed standing up for best results. I couldn't figure out how to save it that way in Cura, so needs to be rotated.

Sketchup files attached.

description.text:
A stand for your Standard Samsung Wireless Charger, you can charge and use your smartphone in both directions.

I made this remix because I can Work and Play games while it charges, and this was great!

The arm has exactly 5mm that fits perfectly between the volume knobs of the S7, creating a protection for not to slide.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

50%

Notes:

It can be printed without supports but the bottom of the circle can get a little bad.
